Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make sure you free all the memory blocks after processing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the DL_DELETE does not free memory

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: you free the pointer called tmp  right ?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
jl777c#5810
Content: eventually data needs to be freed too

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if chk->data is a pointer that was allocated, that needs to be freed. if it is an array of fixed size then freeing chk frees it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what is the struct datachunk look like?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: `struct datachunk { struct datachunk *next,*prev; uint8_t data[8095]; uint16_t datalen; };`

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 8192 is power of 2

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: the txid and the seq number is added afterwards

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I spent a while, y rial and error to get the exact maximum size allowed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ok, so it adds up to 8192?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: not exactly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess it is needed to be matched up to opreturn

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but best to not have it odd

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: is what marketmaker takes as max

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that causes memory alignment issues and can slow things down a lot in some cases

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: but it has tpo be under that, so it comes out as 8131

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i have even seen some primitive OS crash with misalinged

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: with txid and seqid added it is 8131 .. should I reduce it a litle to make it even ?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: it works ok with 200kb sent in RPC at once, but at 2MB it crashed after 15 calls.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: the balster appears to keep up with nearly any amount ot data sent .. it receives it, splits inot chunks and adds to queue ... lots of tricky loops

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: took a while to work out

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: struct datachunk *next,*prev; uint8_t data[8095]; uint16_t datalen;

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what i dont like is datalen is on an odd boundary

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: ok will reduce it by 1 .. shouldnt make mush difrence as long as I do all the numbers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the entire structure is odd size, not a multiple of 8

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make all structure sizes divisible by 8 and all non-byte items aligned to its size boundary and you will avoid a lot of very difficult to track down bugs

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: ignore this advice and you will waste hours chasing misalinged memory problems. I wasted plenty of hours on such so no sense for you to do the same

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just make sure all 2 byte things are at even offsets

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: 4 byte things at offsets evenly divisible by 4

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and 8 byte and bigger on offsets divisible by 8

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: make the total struct size (verified by printing sizeof(struct xxx)) to be a multiple of 8 or even 16

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: add padding bytes if needed

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: no worries, shouldnt be too hard to change it, I have a feeling its only the max sizes in the loops, the rest just counts incrementally...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: was a lot of trial and error to get the data to split up, as 8kb rpc calls were totally usless, normal TX would be faster in that case.
